content: The "Cost of Higher Education Review Act of 1997" was established to address the significant increase in tuition at public colleges and universities, which outpaced the rise in household income and consumer goods costs. Concerns about college affordability were at an all-time high, making college education one of the most expensive investments for American families. The "National Commission on the Cost of Higher Education" is established by the "Cost of Higher Education Review Act of 1997" to address the rising tuition costs at public colleges and universities. The Commission consists of 7 members appointed by various leaders and the Secretary of Education. Each member must have expertise in higher education finance, Federal financial aid programs, education economics research, higher education administration, or business efficiency and cost reduction programs. The Commission consists of 7 members appointed by various leaders and the Secretary of Education. Members must have expertise in higher education finance, Federal financial aid programs, education economics research, higher education administration, or business efficiency and cost reduction programs. The Commission elects a Chairman and Vice Chairperson, with the Vice Chairperson assuming duties in the absence of the Chairperson. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for business transactions, and all appointments must be made within 30 days of the Act's enactment. If an appointment is not made within 30 days, the Chairman of the Committee on Education and the Workforce may act for the Speaker of the House of Representatives. The House of Representatives and Senate leaders appoint members to the Commission. Each member has one vote, vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers, and members cannot receive additional pay. Members of the Commission appointed by House and Senate leaders have one vote each and cannot receive additional pay. Private citizens may receive travel expenses for their service. The Commission's initial meeting must occur within 40 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission appointed by House and Senate leaders have one vote each and cannot receive additional pay. Private citizens may receive travel expenses for their service. The Commission's initial meeting must occur within 40 days of the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. FUNCTIONS OF COMMISSION. The Commission will study and make recommendations on the increase in tuition, methods to reduce tuition, trends in administrative costs, faculty workload and remuneration, faculty-to-student ratios, and tenure practices. The Commission will study trends in construction and renovation of collegiate facilities, modernization for new technologies, impact of financial aid on tuition increases, and the influence of laws and regulations on tuition. The Commission will study the impact of laws, regulations, and financial aid on tuition increases, and make recommendations for reducing mandates. They will also establish a mechanism for distributing data on tuition trends and other costs, and submit a final report to the President and Congress within 120 days. The Commission will make recommendations for administrative and legislative action, requiring a majority vote for adoption by the President and Congress. The Commission has powers to make recommendations for administrative and legislative action, subject to approval by the President and Congress. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, adopt rules and regulations, and request information from federal agencies for the purpose of carrying out the Act. The Commission, under the Freedom of Information Act, can request information from federal agencies. The head of any agency can provide facilities, services, and personnel to assist the Commission. The Commission is also allowed to use the United States mails like other federal agencies. The Commission can enter into contracts for research, appoint staff, and set compensation without following certain federal regulations. The Commission can appoint an Executive Director and additional staff at rates not exceeding the maximum rate for level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Commission is authorized to appropriate up to $650,000 for its expenses, with funds remaining available until expended or one year after the Commission's termination. The Commission will cease to exist 60 days after submitting its final report as required by section 4(b).
